Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän! Al Ana approaching to port!
@BATTLE
All right, get me a damage report as soon as possible. I don't want any disasters sneaking up on us.
Tabii efendim. I agree completely.
Sir, we have a distress signal coming in.
Is anyone on the radio?
Captain, are you there?
This is the captain speaking. Who is this?
Marco DiMarco, sir.
Well - hello, DiMarco.

Fields.MenuText: How have you been?
What can I do for you?
What's wrong?

Fields.DialogueText: Not great, sir. It seems I've gotten into some trouble.
Well, sir, I hate to call in a favor, but I could use your help. I've gotten into some trouble.
Haha, no time for pleasantries, I see. I'm afraid I've gotten into some trouble.
And what would you like me to do?
Any chance you could pick me up in Italy?
Dikkat! Another enemy fleet approaching, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
That attack put us a little behind schedule - but we've finally arrived at La Spezia.
Thank you, Yavuz. Any idea how soon DiMarco will meet us?
I have someone posted to keep an eye out for him, and DiMarco will be directed to us once he arrives.
Good.
So. How much trouble do you think he's in?
I don't think he'd reach out to us unless he was really worried. So, since you ask, I think he's in a lot of trouble.
Ha! You can say that again.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, DiMarco, no, I'm sure everything will be fine.
It's good to see you, DiMarco. I'm just sorry it's under these circumstances.
Ah, here is the troublemaker himself. Glad you made it here safely, DiMarco.

Fields.DialogueText: You keep thinking that, Captain.
Haha, me too, Captain. Me too.
Thank you, Captain. Sorry for pulling you all into this.
We're going to do everything we can to help you out, DiMarco.
So go rest up for a while, and then we'll talk about what's going on.
Thank you. I think I remember my way to my bunk.
Well, this should be interesting.
All right, DiMarco. Tell us what's going on.
Well, where to begin? I guess... Have you ever heard of the Natale family?
The Natale family? You mean that group of mobsters out of Naples?
The very one. A while ago, Vincenzo Natale, the head of that family, strongly suggested I lend him my services.
Strongly suggested?
My sister's kid racked up some gambling debts with the Natales. Vincenzo told me if I wanted him to give Franco some leniency with his debts, then I would investigate his wife for him.
What did he suspect his wife was doing?
The usual things. I tracked the wife down and took pictures of her *ahem* fraternizing with one of Vincenzo's employees.

Fields.MenuText: So he blew a gasket.
Ha, I bet that made his hackles rise.
So now he wants her head on a platter.

Fields.DialogueText: That's one way of putting it.
That's one way of putting it.
That's one way of putting it.
So how does you finding proof of his wife's affair get you in trouble? You were just doing what you were told.
At first he was just angry with me for proving his suspicions were correct, but then...
But then?
Vincenzo wanted me to tell him where his wife was. I didn't think that was a good idea, so I refused.
And now Vincenzo is threatening you in order to make you tell him his wife's whereabouts.
Exactly.
Why don't you think it would be a good idea to tell Vincenzo where his wife is? Do you think he would try to hurt her?
I'm sure he would.
So we need to find a way to smooth things over with Vincenzo while still protecting the wife.
Any ideas?
It will have to wait for now. Al Ana approaching.
@BATTLE
Ah! The familiar rocking of cannonfire. I'll be in a closet somewhere.
Have fun with that.
To battle stations!
@BATTLE
Bu tuhaf. Kapitän, there's someone on the radio.
Who is it?
I'm not sure. There's a lot of interference.
This is... I'm trying to contact... Please...
Say again. Over.
...is Franco Di... please... looking for Mar... I need... in Germany...
Franco! That must be my nephew. He was in Germany last I talked to him. He's in trouble?
It seems so.
...Please, come to Germany... I made a mis... with the Natales...
Looks like Natale might be targeting Franco as well.
Yavuz, try to get more information from him and advise him how to stay safe until we arrive.
Evet, Kapitän.
We'll keep him safe, DiMarco. Don't worry.
Thanks, Captain.
Did he say his last name was DiMarco? I thought he was your sister's kid.
He is. I wouldn't mind if his father found himself in trouble with the Natales, if you understand my meaning.
My sister didn't always make the best choices, but she worked hard to make sure Franco had a good life. I helped her raise him.
Now that Franco's grown, I probably don't look in on him as often as I should. He tends to get in over his head...
Well, like I said, we'll keep him safe. You can count on that.
*sigh*
Okay, I've been putting it off, but we have other business in Wilhelmshaven. Now's as good a time as any.
Is this weird for you?
Ne? Being back in Germany?
You haven't been able to spend much time here since you first went to the Adriatic. Do you miss it?
Sometimes. Lately I've been so busy, I hardly have time to think... let alone get nostalgic.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose that's true.
Even so, this was your home. You must miss it, at least a little.
Oh, I see, you're just a lot more at home out on the ocean, huh?

Fields.DialogueText: If I missed anything, I think it would just be festivals. The people never needed much of a reason to throw a party.
Sometimes, if I hear "Lili Marlene" on the radio or something.
I guess I am. It's where everything interesting happens. I wouldn't turn down the opportunity to spend some time here, though.
Well, maybe you can go have a walk around the wharf before we set sail.
Captain, let me introduce you to my nephew, Franco DiMarco.
Welcome aboard, Franco. It's nice to meet you.
Grazie, Captain. Sorry for the imposition.
And this is Lady Yavuz. She... well, she's essential to the running of the ship.
It's nice to meet you, Franco.
Um... Hi... Miss... Uh...
Yeah, all right, champ - let's get you settled in.
What was that about?
You can be a very intimidating woman, Yavuz.
Bununla ne demek istiyorsun? All I said was it was nice to meet him.
Well then, it must not have been your words that were intimidating.
I suppose it must have been my armament.
@BATTLE
All right, Franco, it's your turn to tell us what's going on.
Bene. Very well, sir. Um... Well... You see...
No need for bashfulness, Franco. Just tell us what happened.
Fine... Money has always been a bit tight for Mom and me. With the war, it was only getting harder. I thought, maybe, if I could figure out a way to work a gambling ring...
You mean a way to cheat a major crime family.

Fields.MenuText: Yavuz...
I'm sure he didn't mean...
I give you points for ambition, if not good sense.

Fields.DialogueText: No, she's right.
No, she's right.
That's fair.
I'm not necessarily proud of it, but I'm not ashamed of it either. The money was dirty to begin with, I just thought I could reappropriate it for better use.
So you tried to cheat them.
And they caught me. But instead of just threatening me, they fixed the game so I would lose badly. It seemed like they were going to just let me work it off...
But then I refused to tell Vincenzo where his wife was, and he decided to take it out on you. I'm sorry, Franco.
We all know it's my own fault. You wouldn't have even been working for Vincenzo if I hadn't messed things up.
How much do you owe him?
More than I can ever hope to pay. That was the idea.
So we'll have to find a way to either get back in Vincenzo's good graces or just completely outsmart him.
Sounds like your area of expertise, Lady Yavuz.
*ALARM*
Hold that thought. DiMarco, show your nephew to the closet, please.
Aye, sir.
@BATTLE
Any ideas of how we're going to handle this Natale situation?
Evet. Several. Do you want them by order of practicality or amount of luck it would take to pull off?
Let's narrow it down. Are we placating Vincenzo or outwitting him?
Probably a bit of both. If we rely too much on the latter and Vincenzo ever figures it out, then we'd leave the DiMarcos vulnerable to reprisals.
But there's no way we're giving him anything valuable enough to appease him in and of itself, so some amount of trickery must be involved.
Could we just fake the DiMarcos' deaths?
No. Relies too much on trickery. The DiMarcos would still have to live in hiding the rest of their lives in order to pull it off.
Any chance we could just have him run into a Morgana?
If only.
Looks like we get to do that ourselves.
@BATTLE
We obviously can't use the Morganas, but what about sending someone else after him?
You mean the enemy of our enemy sort of thing? I would think, given what Vincenzo does, any of his enemies would have a similar policy of wanting something in return.
Maybe not all of his enemies...
What are you thinking?
We need to talk to the DiMarcos.
There's a part of me that would really like to just send Vincenzo a message saying the boys are essential to the war effort.
Play the patriotism card? It's an idea.
Unfortunately, probably not. I think Vincenzo's construction businesses have friends in the Italian government. If we tip him off that the DiMarcos are here, he could start calling in favors.
We could deal with it, I'm sure. But I'd really rather not.
Marco, Franco, we need as much information on the Natale family as you can give us.
Where should we start?
What do you know about the wife and her... uh... friend?
Vincenzo's wife is Giada Oberti-Natale, from the notable Oberti family.
Notable for?
Officially, they own a reputable bank. Unofficially, they move money for the Natale family.
And who is her friend?
Her driver, Santino Romano. There's not much of note where he's concerned.
How involved is Giada in her husband's business?
Vincenzo intentionally keeps her out of it.

Fields.MenuText: Because he actually cares about her and doesn't want her implicated?
Because he's worried she'd make business harder?
Because that's part of his business model?

Fields.DialogueText: Ha, no.
No, Giada wouldn't be a problem.
Exactly.
All of Vincenzo's money is kept in accounts belonging to Giada's family. It can't be explicitly traced to him.
So if Vincenzo ever goes down, all of his money is safe with the Obertis. And Giada has access to those accounts?
She's one of the bank officers.
That is definitely something we can use.
Yavuz, I like that look on your face. It means you're being devious. What do you have planned for Vincenzo's money?
Tüm iyi zamanında - I'll tell you later.  First, we have an unwelcome visitor to take care of.
@BATTLE
All right, Yavuz. Out with it. What's your plan?
It's moderately practical, but we'll need quite a bit of luck.
Ha. Sounds right up your alley.
So Vincenzo is sure to have people looking for Giada and Santino.
Yes...
And Giada and Santino are sure to be looking for a way to get beyond Vincenzo's reach.
Sure...
We can offer them that. We'll offer to get them out of the country - no questions asked and no official reports - for a stiff fee, of course.
Which Giada will take from Vincenzo's account at Oberti Family Bank...
And which we will graciously return to Vincenzo in exchange for him forgiving the DiMarcos.

Fields.MenuText: What if Vincenzo doesn't think getting paid with his own money is enough of a payoff?
What if Vincenzo still wants Giada and Santino?
How are we going to make sure Giada and Santino come to us?

Fields.DialogueText: Haha! That's what the contingency plan is for.
That's what the contingency plan is for.
We'll just have to make sure we're their only option.
You're really enjoying having all the answers and letting the rest of us play catch-up, aren't you?
Evet. Always, sir.
Well, wipe that smile off your face and get ready for battle. Morgana approaching from the north.
@BATTLE
Sound the alarm! Şirketimiz var!
@BATTLE
All right, boys, time for the photos.
Photos?
Lady Yavuz needs photos of us for the report of our deaths.
I thought faking their deaths wasn't an option.
Not a permanent option, but it will help buy us some time as we try to get in contact with Giada and Santino.
Is this the official report?
That it is.
Yavuz, this says I was impaled by a rogue support beam during a battle...
What's your point?
And this says Franco died of... scurvy?!

Fields.MenuText: You're really letting yourself have fun on this one, Yavuz...
What? It happens all the time.
I knew we should have ordered more oranges...

Fields.DialogueText: Don't ruin this for me.
Franco really should have taken better care of himself.
We always forget about that.
Really, the details don't matter much. Vincenzo will be too occupied trying to find another way of locating his wife to question the report.
I hope you're right.
Trust me, DiMarco. It will work.
Aye, Lady Yavuz.
What are you working on?
I'm trying to figure out what the best way to get this paper out would be.
The notice that we'll provide discreet transportation for fugitives...?
Obviously. We can't send it through our normal channels. We need to find the balance between being under-the-table and still being reputable...
Because Giada wouldn't go near anything too dubious.
Exactly. Aferin!
Franco had more interaction with the family's operation itself. Perhaps he knows what sources they use for information?
Uh huh, sure, why don't we bring Franco up here?
Why are you doing that?
Doing what?
Making that stupid face and using that stupid voice like there's something to be insinuated.
I mean, you have to have noticed.
Noticed what?
If Franco isn't getting tongue-tied around you, he's eagerly agreeing with everything you say.
So he's shy and agreeable... good traits for a man, I'd say.

Fields.MenuText: So he's a love-sick puppy.
So he's a bit smitten with you.
So you're pretty and clever, and he's thinking a winter wedding.

Fields.DialogueText: Nope. Hayır - o değil. Nuh-uh.
What? But... I mean... Why?
Ack. Stop it.
Haha, it's not anything to get upset about. It's just a little crush.
Just stop talking about it.
Yavuz...
You'd have to anyway. Al Ana approaching.
@BATTLE
Kapitän! Al ana on the horizon!
@BATTLE
You know, Franco, you don't have to hide in the closet whenever there's a battle.
Lo so. It's just a matter of habit now.
That's fine, too.
Kapitän, I'm going to go do a quick check of the crew.
No, that's all right, Yavuz. I'll do it.
Kapitän...
Well, I really should be working on... something...
So... you spent time in Turkey?
Evet. Yes.
I've read some folklore from Turkey. It was quite interesting. Perhaps we could just have Al Basti come and wreak havoc on the Natale family!
You're suggesting we summon a malevolent female spirit to go haunt the dreams of Vincenzo and drive him insane so he can't work anymore? ...Have a better idea?
Well, you know, not literally. I was making a joke.
Mmhmm.
...Right. So... what's your favorite Turkish legend?
I need to go... do... things.
We've put our message out about taking on passengers - now we just need to make sure Giada and Santino come to us. As far as we know, they're still in Italy, yes?
Yes. The last time I saw them they were settled in Terni.
That's pretty central, so getting to them won't be a problem.
Yes. Katılıyorum. So what else can we do?
Have we considered slipping Vincenzo a hint of their whereabouts? If they think he's closing in, they might be more likely to be on the move.
No, we haven't considered that - because the whole reason we're doing this is because Marco didn't feel right about giving Vincenzo the location.

Fields.MenuText: Easy, Yavuz...
Yavuz's right.
Hold on, Franco might be onto something.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe Franco's right.
I'm not so sure. Maybe it could work.
I agree. Just consider it for a moment.
We would just need to get him close enough to make Giada a little uncomfortable. Maybe we say she headed northwest of Naples, or that they were spotted somewhere in Umbria.
And you don't think that would be dangerous for them?
I don't know, but do we really have any other options?
We'll think about it.
Think about it later. We have visitors.
@BATTLE
You look cross.
DiMarco decided we should give Vincenzo a clue about where Giada and Santino are.
You think that's the wrong call?
I think it could be.
Well, that's why we have your brain working toward the solution. If anyone can work out a narrow escape...
Are you sending it through the back channels again?
Evet. Of course. Why?
Why wouldn't we just have DiMarco tell Vincenzo himself and hope that smooths things over?
Because Vincenzo would probably figure out DiMarco knows more that what he let on and order the hit on him again.
So we use back channels, and we use discretion.
And we hope for the best.

Fields.MenuText: It'll be okay, Yavuz.
I have the utmost faith in your ability to navigate this.
Haha! But we are the best, Yavuz.

Fields.DialogueText: We'll see.
Thank you, Kapitän. Çok takdir ediyorum.
True. We can do this.
On another note - Al Ana trying to sneak up on us.
Here we go.
@BATTLE
Kapitän! You need to hear this.
Not right now. There's a Morgana coming from the east.
@BATTLE
All right, Yavuz, what did you need?
Where's DiMarco?
Right here, Lady Yavuz.
What's wrong?
The pension where Giada and Santino were staying burned down today.
I think it's pretty clear who's responsible.
Do we know for sure?
No, but how could there be any doubt?
...Were they inside?
Thankfully, no. Hopefully that will be more than enough motivation for them to reach out to us.
So now we wait?
Now we wait.
Are you busy?
Does it look like I'm busy?
Well, you're clearly working, but I guess what I'm wondering is if you'd like to take a break.
What do you mean?
Well... Well, I... You see...
Out with it, Franco.
I was wondering if you would like to come with me to get dinner in the mess.
See that? That speck on the horizon? That's an enemy ship approaching - and quickly, too. You should go get comfortable in your closet.
What's going on in here?

Fields.MenuText: Yavuz, are you playing nicely?
Ready for another one, Yavuz?
What's wrong with you?

Fields.DialogueText: Let's just get this annoyance taken care of...
Always, sir.
Nothing, sir. Let's teach this nixe a lesson.
@BATTLE
Which one?
Eating dinner in your quarters, I see. What, did Franco scare you off?
I just needed to be alone.
Ah, come on, now - he's not that bad.
It's not about Franco!
Sorry... I don't mean to be rude. Really, it's not even that I find Franco annoying.
So what is it?
Not that I would ever be interested in Franco... but this... crush... or whatever you call it, it just reminds me of what I'm never going to have.
Someday, Franco is going to meet a girl, he'll fall in love, and he'll spend the rest of his life loving her. That's never going to happen for me.
I don't know why I'm here, I don't know how long I'm going to be here, and I can't even walk away from this ship. There's just no point in thinking about romance.
I'm terribly sorry, Lady Yavuz. I didn't mean anything by it. I'll let you be alone.
Keeping yourself busy, Yavuz?
You were eavesdropping by the door again, I take it?

Fields.MenuText: What? Me? No, I wasn't listening to you complain.
That's how I've found out two-thirds of what I know about you.
Please, you fully knew I was there.

Fields.DialogueText: Go ahead. Say it.
Ack. I'm a bit of a mess, huh?
True. Perks of being the spirit of a ship... So what are your thoughts?
I think it's okay to not know how to feel about things like the future and romance, given how uncertain your future is.
Evet. And thank you.
Oh - and I highly recommend a daily dose of catharsis by beating up Morganas. You ready for it?
Always, sir.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Maybe just try not to take it out on Franco.
And you can let me know if I should politely warn Franco off. You're never going to have a warm meal again if you keep bringing your food down here.

Fields.DialogueText: It's okay. But thank you.
Sound the alarm! Yalnız değiliz!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, did you put this on my desk?
Put what?
There's a rather elaborate paper wolf on my desk.
Wasn't me.
Wow, that looks like it would have taken a lot of time to make.
It was probably Franco, wasn't it?

Fields.MenuText: How close are you to a nervous breakdown right now?
You're not going to burn it if I say yes, are you?
You have to at least applaud him for his persistence.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh, I think I can handle it.
No. It's actually kind of sweet.
I guess so.
Why the wolf?
It's Asena, the mythical she-wolf. She became the leader of one of the first ancient Turkish tribes.
And you love Asena, don't you?
I really do.
Did you ever tell Franco that?
No, I didn't.
Probably just a lucky guess, huh?
Stop it. I know what you're doing.
I'm not doing anything. I'm just saying...
You're just saying that Franco is sweet and thoughtful, and I should give him a chance.

Fields.MenuText: You said it, not me. But... it's interesting that that's where your mind is at.
No comment.
I just want him to stop wasting our paper.

Fields.DialogueText: Hm.
Heh.
Yavuz? Are you in here?
Oh, Kapitän, it's you.
Yavuz, were you... were you hiding behind the desk?
Maybe.
Why?
Franco? Really? I thought you had decided to give him a chance.
Evet! I was trying to. But the last time I spoke to him we started talking about Turkish authors, and I was nice and relaxed...
But...
But then it shifted into more personal territory, and... and... I curtly excused myself and have been avoiding him ever since.

Fields.MenuText: Well, you tried, so that's improvement!
This is too funny.
Wow... Just... Wow...

Fields.DialogueText: How can this possibly be this hard?!
Yeah... Hilarious...
Yeah... I know...
Listen, you sacked Russia's Black Sea ports and sank the Prut. How can this be too scary for you?
I'm more famous for my skills at evasion, so there's that...
Oh, look, there's an enemy fleet. What a perfect distraction.
We're not done with this.
@BATTLE
Sorry, Yavuz.
What luck! Yet another distraction.
@BATTLE
All right, Yavuz. The Morganas have been taken care of, the seas look clear, and we are going to talk about this.
Kapitän, I'm trying - what more do you want from me?
Honestly,Yavuz - stop trying. Just have some fun with it.
What about this is fun?
Well, you have a sweet guy giving you attention without asking anything from you. You know there's no future with him, and I think he knows that too.
There's really nothing to overthink. Instead of trying to figure out the future, you can practice just enjoying the present.
Not everything's a game of chess, and certainly not one you play against yourself.
So you're saying I have to stop thinking.

Fields.MenuText: Dear goodness, woman, yes.
Yes, that's what I'm saying.
Actually, I'm mostly saying you need to stop hiding in places I can't easily get to.

Fields.DialogueText: Fine.
All right.
Okay.
Good. Have fun with that.
Kapitän!
Yes?
Giada Natale contacted us. She commissioned us to pick them up in Italy as soon as possible.

Fields.MenuText: That's great news.
How much are we charging them again?
Wow, our plan is actually working.

Fields.DialogueText: Evet. Everything is going according to plan.
Enough. Does it really matter?
Of course it is; it's our plan.
Someone's getting some of her confidence back.
Is everything in place to carry out the rest of the plan?
Mmhmm. It won't be long before we'll be publishing an article announcing the miraculous resurrections of the DiMarco men.
Assuming they don't tragically die in a battle on the way to Italy. Looks like we have another Morgana on our hands.
That's the spirit.
@BATTLE
What's all the commotion?
That would be everything going according to plan.
What do you mean?
That is the sound of the polizia apprehending two fugitives and confiscating the large amount of stolen cash they have on their person.
What?! That wasn't the plan.
It became the plan when it became clear that the best way to take Vincenzo down would be to take Giada and Santino down as well.

Fields.MenuText: What are you talking about?
Stop being cryptic.
All right, out with it.

Fields.DialogueText: You'll find out soon enough.
Oh, but I'm having so much fun.
Patience, Kapitän.
Just pay attention to the incoming news reports.
@BATTLE
Here it is. Everybody, listen up.
Are they saying what I think they're saying?
Really?
It's true. Now that Vincenzo has been charged with arson, Giada and Santino agreed to testify against him in exchange for reduced sentences. The DiMarcos are free men.
Level with me on this... How long have you had this plan?
Well, I hoped to entrap Vincenzo and get him arrested since we talked about the "enemy of my enemy" idea, but it wasn't until he set their pension on fire that I had a sure way to do it.

Fields.MenuText: So, really, it was mostly luck.
So, really, this could have easily ended much worse.
So, really, you were just pretending to have this all figured out.

Fields.DialogueText: Good thing I'm on a decades-long streak of good luck.
Probably. Good thing it didn't, eh?
Ha. Pretty much.
This is insane. We're really in the clear?
Evet. Really and truly... as long as we beat these monsters on our tail.
@BATTLE
So, how are you going to explain the fact that Marco and I are alive?
I don't need to explain it. There's no arguing with the fact you're alive. That being said, some might wonder how you both were mistaken for dead.
And how will you explain that?
I won't. I'll let the Kapitän handle that.
Did I overhear someone giving me more problems to deal with?
It's hardly a problem, sir. Just let them think you're an idiot.
Excuse me? I'm sorry, but how is that in any way a good idea?
You told me to stop thinking about the future, Kapitän. I'm just following orders.

Fields.MenuText: Ha. You're so pleased with yourself.
My own words used against me...
Oh sure, and have you told Franco what that order was actually about?

Fields.DialogueText: Always, sir.
Sorry, sir. It was too good.
Haha, no need for that, I'm sure.
Yavuz, is that a Morgana over there?
Looks like it. Are you going to head to the closet, or would you like to stay up here with me?
@BATTLE
Well, DiMarco, Franco, it was fun having you around. You're welcome to come back aboard any time - just try to not bring as much trouble with you.
Certamente, Captain.
Thank you, Captain. Let us know if you ever need any investigative assistance.
Will do. Take care of yourselves.
DiMarco, good to see you again. I hope your next job is much less interesting.
Franco, it was nice meeting you.
And you as well, Lady- oh! Um, ahah, until next time, Lady Yavuz!
Yavuz... did you just... kiss Franco on the cheek?
I very well might have.

Fields.MenuText: Well, thank God that's over with.
I'm so proud I might shed a tear.
Good for you, Yavuz.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph.
Ha. Thank you, Kapitän.
Thank you, Kapitän.
